Award.AwardTitle: Upgrading Middlebury College's Floating Laboratory: A State-of-the-Art Research Vessel
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This project replaces the R/V Baldwin, a floating research laboratory used by Middlebury College in Vermont for hands-on, experiential, research training of students on Lake Champlain. The R/V Baldwin has reached the end of its useful life and will be replaced by a new, larger, more highly capable, "green", and seaworthy vessel outfitted to allow college student and faculty research projects to be carried out. Middlebury College is an undergraduate institution that is widely considered as an important engine for educating and training undergraduates who continue on to graduate school in the environmental sciences. The new vessel will double the number of people that can be present on the boat at any given time. Unlike the present vessel, which is restricted to shallow parts of the lake, the new ship will be able to fully navigate the lake, which will dramatically increase the types and numbers of research projects that can be carried out. The new vessel will impact research in disciplines as diverse as geology, biology, environmental science, and chemistry, enabling research in areas as diverse as hydrodynamics, paleoanthropology, paleoclimate, sedimentology, geophysics, aquatic ecology, and environmental chemistry. Broader impacts of the project include increasing the infrastructure for interdisciplinary science and the research training of large numbers of undergraduate students at Middlebury College and other local colleges and universities in Vermont, which is an EPSCoR state. It will also provide jobs in Washington State where the ship will be built. Other impacts include improved environmental assessment and monitoring of the 6th largest freshwater lake in the nation; one that serves the recreational and economic needs of a large number of people in the northeastern US. Research training of K-12 teachers who will use the vessel will be implemented. Public outreach using data collected by researchers using the vessel will be carried out through involvement with local maritime museums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

Funding from this grant and a Major Research Instrumentation award built and equipped a new research vessel to replace Middlebury College’s 24-year-old R/V Baldwin. The Baldwin had been repeatedly retrofitted yet lacked basic facilities and was too small and slow to accommodate increasing demand for research time on nearby Lake Champlain. This lake, a remnant of Pleistocene-era glacial Lake Vermont, is the sixth-largest freshwater body in the United States and contains many historic shipwrecks. The lake and its watershed host 81 fish, 20 reptile and amphibian, 318 bird, and 56 mammal species. It is the major source of drinking water for roughly 200,000 people in Vermont, New York, and Quebec. Centuries of human habitation have left 34 hazardous-waste sites and 95 landfills in the region, and fish consumption advisories (for mercury and PCBs) have been issued for four species in the lake. The region thus presents extensive opportunities for student and faculty research in the biological, chemical, and environmental sciences.

 

The new vessel, R/V David Folger, is an aluminum-hulled catamaran patterned after NOAA vessels. It boasts sediment and water sampling and subbottom sonar survey equipment, a floating laboratory, and smart classroom capabilities--a suite of equipment unparalleled on Lake Champlain. The Folger, which doubled the number of students who can perform research on the lake, was also specifically designed to expand opportunities for lake research in several disciplines at Middlebury, a leader in environmental and science experiential learning and field research.

 

Increasing research capabilities on Lake Champlain will generate new knowledge about the lake, the region, and freshwater lakes in general. With the Folger, Middlebury College will prepare highly qualified candidates to enter professions in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) fields. Many of our students earn advanced degrees in ocean sciences, and the Folger will help us to carry on and expand that tradition.

 

Intellectual Merit

The first research work was scheduled for summer 2012 in Mississqoui Bay, to include senior thesis work by two geology students. The Folger was also slated to be used for Alumni College at the end of the summer and three different Middlebury College courses (Oceanography, Marine Geology, and a First Year Seminar) that fall. However, transport of the vessel to the east coast-- initially scheduled for early May -- was repeatedly delayed by the marine transport company; the Folger didn’t reach Lake Champlain until September. These delays cost a tremendous amount of scheduled research time. The Folger was used during Fall 2012 by several Geology classes; however, many research programs had to be postponed for a year, and the time available for others was severely restricted. In June 2013, the Folger was used for a three-week program of hydrodynamic and sediment studies in Missisquoi Bay. This interdisciplinary project involved undergraduates from Buffalo State College (NY), St. Michaels College (VT), University of Vermont (VT), Middlebury College (MC) and interns from Puerto Rico.
